Do you know that it is a crime in Illinois to throw a snow ball at a tree?
According to a book of crazy laws I have at home (not here), it's only boys that are forbidden to do it. Girls are OK.
next time i'm in snowy illinois, i'll be sure to throw a lot of snowballs (and expecially at trees). :)
Next time it snows (and btw, it snowed sunday night), I'll be sure to throw plenty of snowballs at trees.
yeah, that's right! f*ck the law!

It's just that I think it is a stupid law, it is unenforceable, and probably, most cops don't know about it. And if someone did get arrested for it, they could say that they accidentally hit the tree when they were aiming for something (or someone) else, and get off. So there really is no point to the law.

There's another crazy law that women in Alabama can't wear high heels on the sidewalk. Some woman caught her foot in a crack one time and twisted her ankle. She sued the state for bad sidewalks and they made it a law after that...random fact for ya there...I want to throw a snowball!!!
That's her own fault for not being careful. They shouldn't outlaw it. (Not that police officers probably take the time to enforce it. Or at least the SHOULDN'T!)

personaly i would love to throw a snow ball now or on my b-day but ya know what... IT'S APRIL!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! good bye snow. but next time it does snow i'll make sure to throw some at trees.
 i mean, it's not like the trees are going to fall down or anything
Last year we had snow on the day of my spring band concert (the second wednesday in may). But that was Illinois, where the weather forecasters have already given up trying to predict the weather.
weather forcasters always lie! the man under my friends bed is more right half the time!emoticon_xgood

The job of a weather forecaster (according to one of my former teachers):
 
 1) Make a prediction about the weather that makes sense.
 2) Collect a paycheck whether you're right or wrong.
that actually sounds pretty much like a weather forcaster's job. i think half of them don't really even look at the weather radar that they have.

meteorologists do thier jobs as well as they can. There is always a chance they can be wrong because weather cannot be controlled. Think of how far we've improved, though, from looking at the sky and saying yes, it may rain...
Al Roker (or however it is spelled) of the today show is the worst meteorologist of them all, if he can even be given that title.
Blue laws are great. We have some classic ones in my state.

In The Encyclopedia Britannica is banned in Texas because it contains instructions on how to make beer
 
 In Florida is illegal to sing in public wearing a swimsuit
 
 In Iowa one-armed piano playes must preform for free
 
 In Lexington, Kentucky it illegal to transport ice cream in your pocket 
 
 In Rhode Island it is considered offensive to throw pickle juice on a trolley 
 
 In Wilbur, Washington it is illegal to ride on an ugly horse 
 
 In Clevland, Ohio it is illegal to catch mice without a hunting liscense 
 
 
 
 Aren't those strange????

emoticon_confused 
 How did laws such as the snow ball law and other silly laws come to pass?
 Out of all the conerns of humanity, and this nation who is adressing this???

 Is the snowball going to hurt the tree somehow, anymore than a rock or a boy climbing on its limb.

 I didn't vote for that senator and I'm sure some of the people of Illinois wish they hadn't

I used to live in Illinois, and I had never heard of such a law until it was posted here. It is stupid, and it is extremely unenforcable.

In the town I work in it is illegal to drive upon a freshly mown lawn. One guy actually tacked this onto an arrest last year. Needless to say it made it about as far as the Lt's desk before it was scratched out. He did try though.

see that stuff is so messed up its not like its a big deal Sweatened ice tea has more fat or calories in it so its better if they dont.

Yeah, in Georgia, it's peaches and sweet tea and don't you dare badmouth a Vidalia onion!

 Snow doesn't play a big part in the laws of Australia... as there's very little of it near any large population
 
 I checked out the dumb laws site, with particular interest to my own country, Australia.
 
 I noticed that there's no verifications for where they laws come from ... We do have many jurisdicitons, federal, state/territory, local.
